column1: Causes of respiratory acidosis include: - Diseases of the airways (such as asthma and chronic obstructive lung disease) - Diseases of the chest (such as scoliosis) - Diseases affecting the nerves and muscles that "signal" the lungs to inflate or deflate - Drugs that suppress breathing (including powerful pain medicines, such as narcotics, and "downers," such as benzodiazepines), especially when combined with alcohol - Severe obesity, which restricts how much the lungs can expand - Obstructive sleep apnea Chronic respiratory acidosis occurs over a long period of time.

Smoking leads to the development of many severe lung diseases that can cause respiratory acidosis.
Losing weight may help prevent respiratory acidosis due to obesity (obesity-hypoventilation syndrome).
